results.title: Children of heaven [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Majid Majidi, Mohammad Esfandiari, Amir Esfandiari and The Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults
results.brief_description: Iranian actor turned director, Majid Majidi, has enjoyed commercial and critical success for his humanist portrayals of contemporary Iranian society. “Children of heaven”, nominated for Best Foreign Language Film at the 1999 Academy Awards, is a simple yet tender film about a young boy, Ali, who accidentally loses his sister, Zahra’s, only pair of shoes immediately after having them repaired. Though Zahra is distraught, Ali convinces her not to tell their father, who is already burdened with the responsibilities of supporting a family, including a sick wife, on a meagre wage, and is prone to react violently and irrationally. They agree to keep the news hidden and to share Ali’s one pair of sneakers; an arrangement that involves Zahra rushing from a half day at school at midday to give Ali the sneakers in order for him to attend school in the afternoon. Throughout the film, Ali’s sustained efforts to organise his sister another pair of shoes are continually frustrated. Overall, “Children of heaven” is a poignant, sentimental portrait of class difference in Iran and the struggle of a poor family. It opts for simple imagery - including shots of nature and the children’s faces - to establish a sense of innocence and humanity about its story. It clearly posits the children as the hope of the future - Ali is the top student in his class as well as being physically superior and mature, whilst Zahra is virtuous and innocent. And despite their impoverished circumstances, their innocence ensure these children belong to heaven. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Children of Federation
results.brief_description: This is a look at Australia’s history since Federation in 1901 through the eyes of 6 Gallipoli veterans. As a group of children who came through Federation, they describe what is has been like to have lived in a country that has gone from horse-drawn carriages to the space age. They talk about fashion, music, youth, politics and many other things. They also discuss Australia’s involvement in wars and how they felt, as veterans of Gallipoli, sending their children to World War 2.

results.title: Children of Dune
results.creator_credit: Greg Yaitanes, David Kappes, New Amsterdam Entertainment and Sci Fi Pictures
results.brief_description: Impressive adaptation of two Frank Herbert novels, “Dune Messiah” and “Children of Dune” this made for television mini-series continues the epic science-fiction saga that is “Dune”. On the desert planet of Dune, the ancient prophecy has been fulfilled - the rule of the legendary Maud’dib has triggered a miraculous transformation of the arid wastelands, and where there was once only desert, water now flows. But as always the great Houses of the Empire are awash with political intrigue and betrayal, ambition, desire and destiny. Enhanced by extensive use of CGI, this series ably captures the eerie otherworldliness of Herbert’s desert setting whilst also establishing the requisite mordant tone. Cast includes Alec Newman, Julie Cox, Steven Berkoff and Susan Sarandon.

results.title: Chinatown [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski, Robert Evans, Long Road Productions and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Chandleresque private eye J.J. Gittes takes on the seemingly routine investigation of an errant husband but is soon caught up in a network of private and public evil. Drought-stricken Los Angeles in 1937 is a disorienting and alien place. In this multi-layered narrative, marked by dark humour, the mysterious Chinatown, where social and moral norms don’t operate, acts as a metaphor for a pervasive corruption implicating the past, the present and the future. Stars John Huston, Jack Nicholson and Faye Dunaway. Also availble on VHS [302476].

results.title: Children of alcohol
results.creator_credit: Gil Cardinal, Anne Wheeler, Tom Radford and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This documentary focuses on children of alcoholics. In the relaxed environment of a mountain campsite, a group of young people discuss their anger and frustration, and talk about their struggle to cope with the problems created by their parents’ drinking. By sharing their experiences, they open a door for others like them. Aimed primarily at an audience of elementary school children and older, Children of Alcohol will provide an excellent vehicle for generating discussion about alcohol abuse and the family.

results.title: Children of a lesser god
results.creator_credit: Randa Haines, Patrick Palmer, Burt Sugarman and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on Mark Medoff’s Tony Award-winning (1980) play. It is a touching and poignant love story between a deaf woman and a hearing man. William Hurt gives a sensitive performance as James a likeable schoolmaster, whose job is to teach hearing impaired people to speak. Sarah (Marlee Matlin - who is hearing impaired in real life) is a young beautiful girl who leaves school with a chip on her shoulder and with the knowledge that sex needs no conversation. The touching portrayal of their attraction makes it impossible not to share the experience. Matlin won the 1987 Academy Award for Best Actress with nominations for Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Adapted Screenplay.

results.title: China: The Long March
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Chris Hooke and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: An Australian photographer takes a historic journey retracing the historic trail of the Long March, by which Mao Tse Tung led 100,000 Communist cadres, on foot, across China. Traversing rivers, forests, mountain ranges and wild steppes, the Long March was central to consolidating the Communist Party’s support from the Chinese peasantry. This video offers an excellent historic account of the history of the Long March, as well as offering a breathtaking visual exploration of China and its people.

results.title: China: Sichuan province
results.creator_credit: Shirley Sun and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Sichuan Province, located in central China, is the most populous of all China’s Provinces. This film follows the route of the Chang Jiang (Yangtze River) as it flows eastwards from the mountainous Qinghai-Tibet Plateau to the fertile Sichuan Basin. The video looks at rice and wheat cultivation, mealtimes in a rural household, a government station where farmers sell their produce, and a rural school. The video also examines the people, commerce and industry of Chongqing, Sichuan’s largest city.
